title: The Gut–Brain Axis, Paving the Way to Brain Cancer
abstract:
The gut-brain axis formed by blood and lymphatic vessels paves the way for microbiota to impact 
the brain. Bacterial populations in the gut are a good candidate for a nongenetic factor contributing 
substantively to brain tumor development and to the success of therapy. Specifically, suppression 
of the immune system and induction of inflammation by microbiota sustain proliferative signaling, 
limit cell death, and induce angiogenesis as well as invasiveness. In addition, altered microbial 
metabolites and their levels could stimulate cell proliferation. We propose here a novel gear model 
connecting these complex interdisciplinary fields. Our model may impact mechanistic studies of 
brain cancer and better treatment outcomes through precision oncology.
The Complex Role of Genetics, Immune State, and Microbiome in Brain 
Cancer Development
Tumors of the central nervous system (CNS) represent a major source of cancer-related 
deaths in adults and in children [1]. Studies of the molecular etiology of these devastating 
diseases have elucidated various genetic alterations involving cell survival and DNA repair 
pathways [2]. Rational targeted therapy to these pathways was not effective or showed only 
very mild improvement in survival [3]. In addition to tumor heterogeneity being a major 
obstacle to finding a common and effective treatment, during brain neoplasia there is a 
process of immune suppression, providing an environment that favors tumor growth [4–7]. 
While immunotherapy efforts are under way to disrupt these mechanisms and to turn the 
immune system against developing tumors [8], understanding how the immune suppression 
is initiated is a crucial step toward inhibiting tumorigenesis. We review here the possible 
impact of the gut–brain axis on the immune system state, inflammation, tumorigenicity, and 
response to treatment. Precision medicine taking into account the microbiome’s impact on 
immune suppression and treatment response would result in immune response activation and 
better response to treatment and would increase patient survival.
